item.title: Ticket #3190 (302 status header causes issues on IIS) created
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Problem:

​http://comox.textdrive.com/pipermail/wp-testers/2006-October/003071.html

Proposed solution:

​http://comox.textdrive.com/pipermail/wp-testers/2006-October/003075.html

Success:

​http://comox.textdrive.com/pipermail/wp-testers/2006-October/003083.html

Patch is combined for /branches/2.0/ and /trunk/

I didn't want to commit for /branches/2.0/ before trunk gets fixed... that's how accidental downgrades happen.

item.title: Ticket #3189 (get_children() should use get_posts()) created
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description:
Attached makes get_children() more useful for plugins by going through get_posts().

  2. get_children() calls get_posts().

Please check to ensure backwards compatibility.

item.title: Ticket #3186 (Core shouldn't use deprecated functions) created
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description:
If I look at deprecated.php I see a lot of functions still being used in the core. Isn't the point of deprecating them that we shouldn't be using them anymore?

Here's a list of the functions (and between brackets the files that use them). start_wp (wp-atom.php, wp-rss.php, wp-rss2.php, wp-admin/edit.php, wp-admin/export.php, wp-content/themes/clasdic/comment-popup.php and wp-content/themes/default/comment-popup.php)

wp_set_post_cats (wp-admin/import/dotclear.php and wp-admin/import/textpattern.php)

get_author_link (wp-includes/feed.php)

link_pages (wp-content/themes/default/attachment.php, wp-content/themes/default/page.php and wp-content/themes/default/single.php)

item.title: Ticket #3185 (options.php saves nonce fields and Submit button value) created
item.dc:creator: donncha
item.description:
If you edit the options of a blog directly through options.php it will add options for Update, Wpnonce, and Wp_http_referer. This is because $_POSTpage_options? doesn't exist.

To fix: add each element of the form to an array and run through that array when updating, or just check for the nonce fields.

item.title: 2711.diff attached to Ticket #2711
item.dc:creator: Nazgul

item.title: Ticket #3184 (UTF8 DB connections preferred) created
item.dc:creator: agharbeia
item.description:
There should be an option to affirmatively change the encoding of the database connection to something other than the database server's default.

Many hosts leave their servers at the default of MySQL which is 'latin1' with the 'sewdidh_ci collation'. This messes up many non-Latin-script blogs.

The current solution is to manually add a "mysql_query("SET NAMES utf8 COLLATE utf8_unicode_ci");" statement or similar in wp-db.php which may later get overwritten when upgrading, which complicates things further.

It may be useful to make the default value of this suggested option to actually be UTF8 since it cannot harm Latin-script languages but will be more straightforward for others. Obviously some other people will still need to change the value of this option to have their language scripts correctly encoded and avoid future problems, but it will be a straightforward process by then, instead to have to annually patch the code.

item.title: Ticket #3178 (Import should not fail if file size larger than max php memory) updated
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description:
Hi technosailor,

Sorry for the misunderstanding. As I work to close the tickets, I may have been over zealous with this one. The best time for me to update/close a bug is when I read the bug.

Whether open or closed it does not affect your ability to reopen with a new proposed solution.

When reporting bugs it is better to write in a way that separate the problem from possible solutions. This improves a bugs longevity, if a solution is not presented in a short amount of time.

Thank you, Lloyd

item.title: Ticket #1070 (404 error because of common server setting) updated
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description:
Keywords changed

The code mentioned in the original ticket is no longer in trunk, but the 'problem' is still there.

References to index.php are all over the map. Is it worth it to change them all to accomodate different capitalization scenarios?

I think it has quite a high impact and low usage. What do you guys think?

But I've created a patch based on the comments in this ticket. Only I'm unable to do some real testing, because I don't have a Mac.
